questions.question: Antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC) is seen with:
questions.explanation: Antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC) is mediated by NK cells, neutrophils andeosinophils (killing certain parasitic worms like helminths via IgE antibodies).In ADCC, cells/ antigens are coated with IgG antibodies. These are killed by effector cells like NKcells and macrophages. These effector cells bind to the target by their receptors for the Fcfragment of IgG and cell lysis proceeds without phagocytosis.

questions.question: Which of the following occurs due to gain-of-function mutations in NOD-Like receptors?
questions.explanation: The gain of function mutations in NOD-Like receptors (NLRs) result in periodic fever syndromescalled autoinflammatory syndromes.They are a group of clinical conditions characterised by recurrent inflammatory episodes. Thisdisorder is marked by abnormally increased inflammation, mediated predominantly by cells andmolecules of the innate immune system, with a significant host predisposition.NOD-like receptors are cytosolic receptors that signal via a cytosolic multiprotein complex calledthe inflammasome. This activates caspase-1 that generates biologically active form of interleukin-1(IL-1). IL-1 is a mediator of inflammation that recruits leukocytes and induces fever. Theautoinflammatory syndromes respond very well to treatment with IL-1 antagonists.Note: Autoimmune diseases result from T and B-lymphocyte reactions against self-antigens.

questions.question: What is the normal CD4+: CD8+ T lymphocyte ratio?
questions.explanation: Normal CD4+: CD8+ T lymphocyte ratio is 2:1. Approximately 60% of mature T cells are CD4+and about 30% are CD8+.T-lymphocytes (thymus-derived cells) constitute 60-70% of peripheral blood lymphocytes. T-cellprogenitors are derived from the bone marrow, but travel to the thymus, where they mature. Tcells can be divided into three main subtypes:They are located in the paracortical areas of lymph nodes and the periarteriolar sheaths ofthe spleen. They have an antigen-specific T-cell receptors (TCR) which have alpha/betapolypeptide chains components. Demonstration of TCR gene rearrangement by southern blot is amolecular marker of T-cell lineage.The CD molecules present on T cells are CD1, CD2, CD3, CD4, CD5, CD7, CD8 and CD28. CD3 isinvolved in signal transduction and is also called a pan T-cell marker. CD40 ligand on the surfaceis required for B-cell activation and induction of immunoglobulin.266Type of T cellHelper T cell (CD4+)Cytotoxic T lymphocytes (CTLs or CD8+)Regulatory T cellsFunctionHelps B lymphocytes to make antibodies and activate other leukocytes to destroy microbesKill infected cellsLimit immune responses andprevent reactions against self-antigens.

questions.question: Which of the following are the most important antigen-presenting cells?
questions.explanation: Dendritic cells or interdigitating dendritic cells are the most important antigen-presentingcells. They initiate T-cell responses against protein antigens.They are located in the epithelium and interstitium. They express many receptors for capturingand responding to microbes (and other antigens), including toll-like receptors (TLRs) and lectins.They also express high levels of major histocompatibility complex (MHC) for presenting antigensto and activating T cells.In response to microbes, dendritic cells are recruited to the T-cell zones of lymphoid organs. Here,they present antigens to T cells with help of MHC.Similar cells with dendritic morphology in the germinal centers of lymphoid follicles in the spleenand lymph nodes are follicular dendritic cells. They bear Fc receptors for IgG and receptors forC3b. Immature dendritic cells within the epidermis are called Langerhans cells.Note:.•Aggretope part of the antigen associated with the MHC molecule on the antigen-presenting cell-• Epitope - antigenic part of contact with the T-cell receptor267

questions.question: Which of the following statements is false about macrophages?

options.A: It acts as an antigen presenting cell
options.B: It plays a role in humoral immunity
options.C: It plays a role in cell-mediated immunity259
options.D: It is a component of innate immunity only

questions.explanation: Macrophages are components of both innate and acquired immunity.They phagocytose microbes and protein antigens. They process the antigens and present thepeptide fragments to T cells. Thus, macrophages function as antigen-presenting cells in T-cellactivation.They also participate in the effector phase of humoral immunity. Macrophages efficientlyphagocytose and destroy microbes that are opsonized (coated) with IgG or C3b.They are key effector cells in certain forms of cell-mediated immunity to eliminate intracellularmicrobes. In this type of response, T cells activate macrophages and enhance their ability to killingested microbes.

questions.explanation: CD80 (B7-1) and CD86 (B7-2) are the costimulatory molecules present on antigen-presenting cells(APCs). They bind to CD28 protein present on T cells. This promotes the expansion ofantigen-stimulated T cells and their differentiation into effector and memory cells.T-cell activation requires two signals that are delivered by APCs. They include:•Antigens displayed by APCs in the form of peptides bound to MHCmolecules, that are recognised by T-cell receptors• Costimulatory signal (as it stimulates T cells in conjunction with antigen) provided by moleculeson APCs that engage particular costimulatory receptors on T cellsIn the absence of costimulation, T cells that recognize antigen either fail to respond and die orenter a state of unresponsiveness known as anergy. questions.question: In which of the following cells is recirculation seen?

options.C: Both plasma cells and T lymphocytes261
options.D: Both B lymphocytes and plasma cells

questions.explanation: Lymphocyte recirculation is seen in T lymphocytes.Migration of the lymphocytes between blood and lymphoid organs is called recirculation. Naivelymphocytes traverse the peripheral lymphoid organs, where immune responses areinitiated. When antigen-presenting cells activate them, the effector lymphocytes migrate to sites ofinfection and inflammation.272In contrast, plasma cells remain in lymphoid organs and the bone marrow. They do not need tomigrate to sites of infection because they secrete antibodies that are carried to distant tissues.

questions.question: Among the following, which cells have MHC class II?

options.C: B cells, dendritic cells, mononuclear phagocytes

questions.explanation: Class II major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecules are mainly expressedon macrophages, B lymphocytes, and dendritic cells. These cells present ingested antigens toT-cells.The function of MHC molecules is to display peptide fragments of protein antigens for recognitionby antigen-specific T cells. In humans, the MHC molecules are called human leukocyte antigens(HLA) because they were initially detected on leukocytes by the binding of antibodies. Thecombination of HLA alleles in each individual is called the HLA haplotype.The genes encoding HLA molecules are clustered on the short arm of chromosome 6.Uses of MHC/ HLA typing include:•Anthropology• Transfusion•Paternity testing••• Forensic scienceTransplantation273• Disease correlation
